subject: Marketing
title: The Anchoring Effect
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Anchoring Effect.

hook.text: Judges given random numbers before sentencing gave harsher sentences after higher numbers.

buildup.text: Anchoring means the first number you see distorts every number that follows.

discovery.text: Retailers show the original price crossed out so the sale price feels like a bargain.

twist.text: The anchor doesn't even need to be relevant. Any big number shifts perception upward.

climax.text: Luxury brands set extreme anchors so that even their cheapest item feels accessible.

punchline.text: The first number wins the negotiation.

quiz.question: How does anchoring affect price perception?
options: The first number seen distorts all subsequent judgments
It only works with relevant price comparisons
Consumers can easily override anchoring bias
